qas.question: What are editors trying to ultimately accomplish?

answers.text: our ideal of an author's fair copy of his work in its final state

qas.question: If an editor can't achieve an exact reproduction of an authors work, what should be the goal?

answers.text: approximate as nearly as possible an inferential authorial fair copy

qas.question: What did Bower's say about Greg's method?

answers.text: represent the nearest approximation in every respect of the author's final intentions

qas.question: What did Tanselle say about textual criticism?

answers.text: has generally been undertaken with a view to reconstructing, as accurately as possible, the text finally intended by the author

qas.question: What are editors trying to ultimately stop?
What happens when an editor achieves an exact reproduction of an authors work?

plausible_answers.text: represent the nearest approximation in every respect of the author's final intentions

qas.question: What did Tanselle say about modern authors?
Bowers asserted that editions founded on Greg's method would not represent what?

context: McKerrow had articulated <b5_0>textual criticism<b5_0/>'s goal in terms of "<a0_0>our ideal of an author's <b4_0>fair copy<b4_0/> of his work in its final state<a0_0/>". Bowers asserted that editions founded on Greg's method would "<a2_0><b6_0>represent the nearest approximation in every respect of <b7_0>the author's final intentions<b7_0/><b6_0/><a2_0/>." Bowers stated similarly that the editor's task is to "<a1_0>approximate as nearly as possible an inferential authorial fair copy<a1_0/>." Tanselle notes that, "Textual criticism ... <a3_0>has generally been undertaken with a view to reconstructing, as accurately as possible, the text finally intended by the author<a3_0/>".
